light: Medium to bright indirect light; avoid harsh direct afternoon sun which can scorch leaves.
water: Water when the top 3 cm (1 in) of soil are dry. Keep evenly moist in growing season but never soggy; reduce watering in winter.
humidity: Prefers 50–70% humidity but tolerates typical indoor levels if kept away from heating vents.
temp: Ideal 18–27°C (65–80°F); avoid cold drafts and temperatures below about 15°C (59°F).
soil: Loose, well‑draining aroid mix with peat or coco coir, bark, and perlite for both moisture and aeration.
fertilizer: Feed every 4–6 weeks in spring and summer with a balanced, diluted houseplant fertilizer; little to none in winter.
toxicity: Mildly to moderately toxic if ingested (calcium oxalate). Keep away from pets and children that chew plants.
tips: Provide a moss pole or stake for climbing types; rotate regularly for even growth and wipe dust from leaves so they can photosynthesize efficiently.

scientific_name: Various fern genera (Adiantum, Nephrolepis, Asplenium, etc.)
light: Bright to medium indirect light; no direct sun which quickly scorches delicate fronds.
water: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Never allow the root ball to fully dry; reduce slightly in winter.
humidity: High humidity 60–80% is ideal; group plants, use pebble trays or a humidifier, especially for maidenhair and other fine‑leaf species.
temp: Most indoor ferns prefer 16–24°C (60–75°F) with no cold drafts or sudden temperature swings.
soil: Rich, moisture‑retentive but airy mix with peat or coco, compost, and perlite; avoid heavy, compacted soils.
fertilizer: Feed lightly every 4–6 weeks during active growth with a dilute balanced fertilizer; ferns are sensitive to overfertilizing.
toxicity: Many common indoor ferns are non‑toxic, but species vary; when in doubt, treat as potentially unsafe for pets to chew.
tips: Brown, crispy fronds usually point to low humidity or underwatering. Trim damaged foliage and maintain steady moisture and humidity for best appearance.

light: Low to bright indirect light; variegated forms hold color best in medium to bright filtered light.
water: Water when the top 3–5 cm (1–2 in) of soil are dry. Very forgiving of the occasional missed watering; avoid constantly wet soil.
humidity: Average home humidity (40–60%) is fine; appreciates a bit more but does not require it.
soil: Standard well‑draining potting mix with added perlite or bark to prevent compaction.
fertilizer: Feed monthly in spring and summer with a balanced fertilizer diluted to half strength.
toxicity: Toxic if ingested (calcium oxalate); keep out of reach of pets and children.
tips: Great as a hanging or climbing plant. Leggy growth indicates it needs more light; prune vines to encourage fuller, bushier growth and easily propagate cuttings in water.
